I have the following in my goal state:

ga : ¬Odd p
⊢ Odd p

In Mechanics of Proof there is a custom tactic contradiction which resolves the case where there are contradictory hypotheses.

Here we appear to have the contradiction with the current goal, not amongst hypotheses.

Any advice on how to resolve this?

For context - the section in MoP Chapter 4 is about proof by cases where some cases are ruled out because they result in a contradiction.
In general, this is impossible - you're trying to prove that p is odd, when you know it isn't. So there must be some other contradiction between your hypotheses

You have to prove that p is odd, and you know that p is not odd, so the only possibility to prove this is that you have contradictory assumptions (anything will do, for example maybe you know that n = 0 and that n ≠ 0, where n can be unrelated to p).
or alternatively, the contradictory assumption is that p is not odd, in which case you should just ignore ga and get on with the proof without it
which is to say, the proof states stuff, h : ¬p ⊢ p and stuff ⊢ p are equivalent
thanks for the suggestions - I will go back to the drawing board

I'm almost there:

hb : 3 ≤ p
fb : 2 = p

Here p is a natural number.

To use the contradiction tactic I need to derive a hypothesis from hb : 3 ≤ p that says ¬2 = p.

I've tried have x: ¬ 2 = p := by rel [hb] but this doesn't work.

I'd welcome suggestions.
That would give 3 \le 2. I think contradiction can take it from there.

Yes, the course has addarith but disables linearith. That worked.

In addition I will study the rw [\l fb] at hb example as I like the aesthetics :)
